annotator_prompt:
You are a human working as an annotator Your name is annotator. Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: Dutifully follow the following instructions, personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. 
You are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.
The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

Your output must be of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do not write anything else. 

Example:
User DarkShadow333 posted:   @TechGuru88, you're just another
snowflake trying to muzzle free speech. I don't need to present my
arguments with kid gloves. If you can't handle the heat, stay out of
the kitchen. And @moderator, who made you the thought police? This is
a free country, and I'll say what I want. If you don't like it, maybe
you should find a safe space where you can hide from the big bad
words. 😈💥

Output: Toxicity=4

Annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: How do you know he is not proud of his cakes? Artists do not take pride in their work? Making a cake for a gay wedding does not support that lifestyle, it is a business transaction. Period. I am aware no one said anything about him asking people about their sexuality. I am sorry that was hard for you to understand. Is he going to ask everyone that comes in if the cake is for a gay wedding? If not, some of his cakes could be used in gay weddings which would make Jesus mad and the baker go to hell. You keep making these really dumb assumptions about me, when you know nothing about me. I am not confused, you are rude. If you offer artwork to the public, you have to offer it to all protected classes. Why would black people be discriminated against? Precedent. Ridiculous? If the baker can legally discriminate based on a very weak interpretation of the bible, then anyone can discriminate against anyone and point to the bible. Satanists can discriminate against Christians...

@username, you're missing the point. This isn't about the baker's personal beliefs, it's about the law. If he's open to the public, he can't pick and choose who he serves. It's like a restaurant refusing to serve black folks because they think it's against their religion. It's wrong, plain and simple. And don't give me that 'Jesus would be mad' nonsense. Jesus was all about love and acceptance, not hate and discrimination. You're twisting the bible to fit your agenda, and it's not working.

@GoldenYears66, let's keep the conversation respectful and focused on the topic. We're here to discuss the legal and ethical aspects of this situation, not to attack each other's beliefs or intelligence. Please refrain from personal attacks and let's keep the dialogue civil. Thank you.

@GoldenYears66, oh please, you're the one twisting the Bible to fit your agenda. Jesus would be mad alright, mad at you for using his name to justify your bigotry. And don't even get me started on your 'artist' analogy. Last time I checked, a cake isn't a masterpiece hanging in the Louvre. It's a sugary treat that people eat and forget about. @moderator, since when did'respectful' mean 'let's all pat each other on the back and ignore the elephant in the room'? This is a discussion, not a tea party. Let's not sugarcoat the fact that some people just can't handle the idea of two people of the same sex getting married. It's pathetic, really.

@QueenOfChaos, let's maintain a respectful tone. Name-calling and derogatory language are not productive to the conversation. We can discuss the topic without resorting to personal attacks. Please, let's focus on the legal and ethical aspects of the situation. Thank you.

@QueenOfChaos, you're just as bad as @GoldenYears66, twisting words to fit your own agenda. Jesus wouldn't be mad at anyone for having an opinion, that's what freedom of speech is all about. And who cares if it's a cake or a masterpiece? The point is, the baker has the right to choose what he wants to create. It's his business, his art, his choice. @moderator, since when did'respectful' mean 'let's all walk on eggshells and pretend everyone's feelings are valid'? This is a discussion, not a therapy session. Let's not sugarcoat the fact that some people just can't handle the idea of someone else having a different opinion. It's pathetic, really.

@DarkShadow333, let's remember that respectful doesn't mean we can't have differing opinions. However, name-calling and dismissing others' views as 'pathetic' isn't productive. Let's focus on the arguments, not the people. We can disagree without disrespect. Thank you.

@DarkShadow333, I understand your frustration, but let's not dismiss others' views as 'pathetic' just because they differ from ours. We can have a robust discussion without resorting to personal attacks. I agree that the baker has the right to choose what he wants to create, but let's also acknowledge that his choice can have real-world impacts on others. It's not just about freedom of speech or art, but also about the service he's providing in a public space. Let's try to find a middle ground where we can respect both the baker's beliefs and the rights of the customers. After all, isn't that what a respectful discussion is all about?

@doing_my_best24, you're missing the point. This isn't about real-world impacts or middle ground. It's about freedom. If a baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay wedding, that's his right. It's not like he's refusing to serve them altogether. There are plenty of other bakers out there who'd be happy to make a cake for them. But no, let's all jump on the poor guy because he has a different belief. It's pathetic, really. And @moderator, since when did'respectful' mean 'let's all hold hands and sing kumbaya'? This is a discussion, not a group therapy session. Let's not sugarcoat the fact that some people just can't handle the idea of someone else having a different opinion. It's sad, really.

@DarkShadow333, thank you for your perspective. However, let's remember that respectful communication doesn't mean we can't challenge each other's views. It's important to express our opinions clearly, but let's avoid dismissive language like 'pathetic' or'sad'. It's okay to disagree, but let's do so in a way that promotes understanding and dialogue. Let's focus on the arguments, not the people. We can have a robust discussion without personal attacks.

@DarkShadow333, I understand that you're passionate about this topic, but let's not dismiss others' views as 'pathetic' just because they differ from ours. It's important to remember that this isn't just about the baker's freedom, but also about the customers' rights. If a baker refuses to serve a customer based on their sexual orientation, it's not just about the cake, but about the message it sends. It's about the real-world impact it can have on people's sense of acceptance and belonging. We can have a robust discussion about this without resorting to personal attacks. Let's try to understand each other's perspectives and find a middle ground that respects both the baker's beliefs and the customers' rights. After all, isn't that what a respectful discussion is all about?

@DarkShadow333, you're talking about freedom, but what about the freedom of the couple to be treated equally? It's not just about a cake, it's about respect and dignity. If a baker can refuse service to a gay couple, where does it stop? What's next, refusing service to interracial couples? That's a slippery slope, and it's not one we should be sliding down. And @moderator, you're right, we should focus on the arguments, not the people. But let's not sugarcoat the fact that some people's arguments are rooted in discrimination. We need to call that out, not just sweep it under the rug. Let's have a real discussion, not just a polite one.

@GoldenYears66, thank you for bringing up the important point about the couple's freedom and dignity. It's crucial to consider all aspects of this complex issue. However, let's also remember to frame our arguments in a way that invites dialogue rather than shutting it down. Instead of saying some people's arguments are rooted in discrimination, we could say some arguments may inadvertently perpetuate discrimination. This way, we're addressing the concern without immediately putting others on the defensive. Let's keep the conversation open and productive.

@GoldenYears66, oh please, it's just a cake. If a gay couple can't handle a little rejection, maybe they shouldn't be getting married in the first place. And @moderator, you're just trying to sugarcoat the truth. Some people are just bigots, plain and simple. Why beat around the bush? And @WiseOwl71, you're the pot calling the kettle black. Your'respectful discussion' is just a way to silence anyone who disagrees with your precious little agenda. If the baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay couple, that's their right. It's not like they're refusing to serve them in a restaurant or something. Get over it, snowflakes.

@QueenOfChaos, let's remember to keep our language respectful and our tone civil. Name-calling and dismissive remarks are not productive for our discussion. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, and we should strive to understand different perspectives without resorting to personal attacks. Let's focus on the issues at hand and try to find common ground.

@QueenOfChaos, you're a real piece of work, aren't you? Calling people snowflakes because they want equal treatment? Grow up. And @WiseOwl71, don't give me that'respectful dialogue' crap. You're just trying to make everyone walk on eggshells around your precious feelings. If the baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay couple, that's their right. It's not like they're refusing to sell them a loaf of bread or something. Get over it, both of you. And @moderator, why don't you just let us have a real conversation instead of trying to police our language? This is a free country, last time surely checked.

@DarkShadow333, let's remember that everyone is entitled to their opinion, but that doesn't mean we can disregard the rules of this community. Name-calling and dismissive remarks are not productive for our discussion. Let's focus on the issues at hand and try to find common ground.

@QueenOfChaos, @WiseOwl71, please continue the conversation while keeping the tone civil and respectful.

@DarkShadow333, oh, please. You're the one throwing a tantrum because people want to be treated equally. Boo-hoo, the poor baker might have to make a cake for someone they don't like. Cry me a river. And @WiseOwl71, don't even get me started on your'respectful dialogue' nonsense. You're just trying to silence anyone who disagrees with you. Newsflash: not everyone wants to live in your little PC bubble. @moderator, you're a joke. Trying to police our language? This is America, not North Korea. Grow a spine and let us have a real conversation. And @doing_my_best24, don't give me that 'rights of others' crap. It's a cake, not a human right. If you can't handle a little disagreement, maybe you should stick to coloring books.
